bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, July 8, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg asks if Hench has noted the use of the “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” painting in Morrow's new book. He discusses Pinto's role in the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, July 8, 1942
div1.p:
I enjoyed your letter but I am sorry that
you will not be located at Washington.

Had you noticed that Morrow's new book,
“Ambassadors in White” used Wyeth's Conquerors of
Yellow Fever” as a frontispiece, giving the names
of the characters but not including the group of
names for which certain of the characters were to
be symbolic. The book review of the HEW YORK HERALD
TRIBUNE reproduced the painting with the review of
the book. If I succeed in getting a copy of this
bookpapers at this late date I will forward it to you.

Enclosed find a couple of camp directories
which we just got out for the medical profession.
Camp Gustercarson does not seem to be listed, although it
sounds as if it might be in Wyoming.

Doug Withington and I thought to send you
some of the attached blotters as we believed you would
be interested but I don't know whether he was to send
them, or I. Anyway, I'm sending a package of 25 under
separate cover. You may have some friends who would
like to see them

I am glad to be reassured about Dr. Pinto.
Time has probably built up to himself the importance
of his contribution in the yellow fever research and
the mere fact that he was there at all, of course,
would be something to talk about.

Coming back to Morrow's book, I will be
interested in reading his account of the Yellow Fever
experiments.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
GAK:L
